Probability Intervals - General Normal Distribution

We saw in a previous subsection that \(95\%\) of the area under the standard normal curve lay between \(z_1=-1.96\) and \(z_2=1.96\). Using the formula \(Z=\dfrac{X-\mu}{\sigma}\) in the re-arrangement \(X=\mu+Z\sigma\), we can see that \(95\%\) of the area under the general normal curve lies between \(x_1=\mu-1.96\sigma\) and \(x_2=\mu+1.96\sigma\). This is shown in the Figure below.

Example

Suppose that the internal diameters of mass-produced pipes are normally distributed with mean \(50\) mm and standard deviation \(2\) mm. What are the \(95\%\) probability limits on the internal diameter of a single pipe?

Solution

Here \(\mu=50\) and \(\sigma=2\) so that the \(95\%\) probability limits are

\(\qquad 50\pm 1.96\times 2 = 50\pm 3.92\) mm,

i.e. \(46.08\) mm and \(53.92\) mm.

Hence the probability interval is \((46.08, 53.92)\).
